title: Kenya: Scrap Senate to Pay Teachers - Wangwe
text:
Gambia: 35 Youths Trained On Policy Analysis By Hilton Otenyo 
The Senate should be scrapped and the money saved paid to teachers, Navakholo MP Emmanuel Wangwe has said. 
He said the offer by some senators to have their salaries slashed to pay teachers the court-ordered 50-60 per cent salary increase is not enough. 
Speaking to the Star in Kakamega town yesterday, Wangwe said Kenyans should agree to a quick referendum to remove the Senate, referring to it as "a House of idlers". 
He said the Senate's oversight role can be carried out by the Kenya National Audit Office. 
The agency audits the national and county governments and reports to the Auditor General. 
Wangwe said the Division of Revenue Bill comes from the National Assembly and it can be executed without the Senate. 
Schools remain closed for the third week as the standoff between teachers and the Teachers Service Commission continues. 
The legislator said Treasury CS Henry Rotich's proposal to increase Value Added Tax to raise money to pay teachers is unwarranted as it will overburden Kenyans. Kenya
